results.title: You and hydatids
results.creator_credit: Norman Laird and Tasmanian State Film Unit
results.brief_description: Warns against the danger of humans contracting hydatids through the careless handling of sheep and dog. Explains how, by eating offal from infected animals, the dog becomes the carrier of the disease between sheep and man. The disease my be prevented from spreading by boiling sheep offal prior to feeding to dogs, by carefully washing all vegetables to be eating raw by keeping the dog outside the home and car and by giving the dog regular medical examinations.

results.title: Out of Sight, Out of Mind
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and David Goldie
results.brief_description: ‘Out of Sight, Out of Mind’, in its depiction of prison conditions, helped to raise awareness about a much neglected section of our society. It provided extensive insight into the prison system, interviewing prisoners, prison officers and administrators. There are four parts titled ‘Locked Up’, ‘Surviving in the Nick’, ‘The Keepers and the Kept’, and ‘The Cycle of Crime’. This program pulls no punches, describes the conditions of various correctional institutions around Australia and also offers some suggestions for improvements.

results.title: Just hold still. Parts one and two
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: In his New York City Landscape, Cohen finds inspiration in disturbance. Looking to life for rhythm and to architecture for state of mind, he locates simple mysteries. `Just Hold Still’ is comprised of an interconnected series of short works and collaborations that explore the grey area between documentary, narrative and experimental genres. Part One concerns a personal, poetic approach to narrative while Part Two involves hybridized use of verite footage and the confrontation of documentary concerns with the music video format. The work can be considered as a whole or each piece in the project can be viewed (and rented) as a separate entity.

results.title: KKND: Krush Kill 'N Destroy for DOS
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In the far future of KKND: Krush Kill ‘N Destroy, a nuclear war has destroyed the Earth’s surface. The humans that were left split into two factions: The Survivors are the descendants of humans who managed to burrow under the Earth’s crust before the surface’s annihilation, taking with them what they could salvage. They survived underground for sixty years but dwindling resources has forced them to resurface. They were met by the Mutes, humans who lived through the nuclear destruction, mutated and dominated the Earth. An armed conflict between the two groups is inevitable. The game has you choosing either of these factions. As a classic real-time strategy, the focus on this game is gathering oil, building up and upgrading your base, training units and completing your objectives. Objectives can range from simply destroying an enemy presence to gathering a set amount of materials while fending off enemy attacks.

results.title: Aussie Rules Footy for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.
results.description:
Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

results.title: Powerslide for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description: After an environmental holocaust killed 98% of the world’s population, the survivors above ground turned to modifying and racing the cars left over in the ruins of civilization. In the ruined world of Powerslide, players race through abandoned cities buried in sand, ruins of a dam, abandoned mine shafts, and other desolate landscapes. Perform death-defying jumps and slide through the corners as you eke out each win! This racing sim has full car dynamics, force feedback, and full multiplayer support.
